questions.text: All of the following mutation can be seen in urothelial tumor, except?
questions.solution:
• Non- muscle-invasive papillary cancers of urinary bladder often have gain-of-function alterations that increase signaling through growth factor receptor pathways,
    • amplifications of the FGFR3 (choice C) tyrosine kinase receptor gene
    • mutations in the genes encoding RAS and PI3-kinase. (choice B) Chances to progress to muscle-invasive bladder cancer is 20%)
  • Muscle-invasive bladder cancers develop by progression from "flat" CIS.
    • Mutations of p53 (choice A) and RB are prevalent in all muscle-invasive cancers.
  • PTEN mutation (choice D)is not seen usually in urothelial tumors, it is been reported in other tumors e.g. endometrial tumors, prostate tumors, glial tumors.

questions.text: Which of the following is not the tumor of the urinary bladder?
questions.solution:
Tumors of the Urinary Bladder

  • Urothelial (transitional) tumors (choice A)
    • Noninvasive urothelial (transitional cell) tumors
    • Infiltrating urothelial carcinoma
    • Variants: nested, microcystic, micropapillary, plasmacytoid, sarcomatoid, giant cell, poorly differentiated, lipid-rich, and clear cell
  • Adenocarcinoma (choice B)
  • Squamous cell carcinoma
  • Mixed carcinoma
  • Small-cell carcinoma
  • Sarcomas(choice C)

questions.text: A baby girl has an open defect of the lower abdominal wall (shown in the image). This patient is repaired surgically. Despite the corrective surgery, the child is at increased risk of developing which of the following neoplasms?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of the above patient is bladder exostrophy.

EXSTROPHY OF THE BLADDER:

  • Developmental failure in the anterior wall of the abdomen and the bladder.
  • The bladder communicates directly with the abdominal surface.
  • The exposed bladder mucosa may undergo colonic glandular metaplasia and is subject to chronic infection that often spreads to the upper urinary tract.
  • Exstrophy is associated with an increased risk of adenocarcinoma in the bladder remnant.

questions.text: A 29 years old pregnant woman (gravida II, para I) complains of lower pelvic discomfort, fever and pain during urination since past 4 days. She also mentioned blood in her urine. Which of the following would be the most likely etiologic agent?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of the above case is ACUTE CYSTITIS.

  • Predisposing factors for cystitis:
    • Bladder calculi
    • Urinary obstruction
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Instrumentation
    • Immune deficiency.
  • The most common etiologic agents of cystitis are the coliforms:
  • Escherichia coli > Proteus > Klebsiella > Enterobacter.
  • Women are more likely to develop cystitis as a result of their shorter urethras.
  • Tuberculous cystitis is almost always a sequel to renal tuberculosis.
  • Immunosuppressed patients: Candida albicans > cryptococcal agents and long term antibiotics cause cystitis.
  • Schistosomiasis(Schistosoma haematobium) remains an important cause of cystitis in certain African and Middle Eastern countries.
  • Viruses: (e.g., adenovirus), Chlamydia, and Mycoplasma may also cause cystitis.
    • Adenovirusand BK virus infections may result in HEMORRHAGIC CYSTITIS.
    • Gas-forming bacteria (such as Clostridium perfringens) result in EMPHYSEMATOUS CYSTITIS(gas-filled vesicles in the bladder wall).

questions.text: A 61 years old male patient complains of dysuria, frequency and urgency. She has a long history of urinary tract infections. Urine culture are positive for E. Coli. Cystoscopy reveals soft yellow plaques on the mucosal surface. The microscopic findings are showing mucosal chronic inflammatory cells with macrophages. Which of the following is the marked structure in the following PAS stained image?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of the above case is MALAKOPLAKIA.

  • It is a distinctive chronic inflammatory reaction
  • acquired defects in phagocyte function.
  • It arises in the setting of chronic bacterial infection, mostly by E. Coli or occasionally Proteus species, and occurs in immunosuppresive patients.
  • Cystoscopically: soft yellow, slightly raised mucosal plaques, 3 to 4 cm in diameter.
  • Histologically:
    • aggregates of large foamy macrophages with occasional multinucleate giant cells and lymphocytes.
    • The macrophages have abundant granular cytoplasm(defective phagolysosome function).
    • laminated mineralized concretions resulting from deposition of calcium in enlarged lysosomes, known as MICHAELIS-GUTMANN BODIES, are typically present within the macrophages. (Choice C)
    • Similar lesions have been described in other organs including the colon and other parts of the gastrointestinal tract, brain, lungs, bones, endometrium, kidneys, prostate, and epididymis.
  • Gamna gandy body (choice A)- spleen (spleenomegaly I/c of portal hypertension or sickle cell disease)
  • Schillar duval body (choice B)- yolk sac tumor
  • Cowdry type A body(choice D)- herpes virus infection

questions.text: Which of the following immunohistochemical markers is typically NOT positive in urothelial carcinoma?
questions.solution:
The immunohistochemical markers used to diagnose the urthelial carcinoma are:

CK7

CK20

GATA3

Uroplakin 3

But not CD45- Its expression is not typically seen in urothelial carcinoma

choices.text: Occurs in cases of prior urothelial injury

questions.text: All are true regarding the nephrogenic adenoma, except?
questions.solution:
NEPHROGENIC ADENOMA (previously known as nephrigenic metaplasia)

  • Benign, incidental finding
  • Not a true form of true metaplasia
  • Lesions <1 cm in size
  • Often arise in the setting of prior urothelial injury(choice C)
  • Histogenesis- POSSIBLY DERIVED FROM SHED RENAL TUBULES- stain with PAX8 by IHC (Immunohistochemistry) (choice D)
  • Histologic spectrum:
    • Tubules lined by cuboidal to columnar cells
    • Papillary structures +(choice B)
    • Cells can be hobnailed
    • Often thick basement membrane
    • No significant nuclear atypia
    • Fibromyxoid variant has spindled cells surrounded by fibromyxoid stroma

questions.text: Which of the following etiologic agent is NOT responsible for urothelial carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Bladder tumors- causes

  • Chemicals known to increase the risk of bladder cancer :-
    • Petrochemicals
    • Arylamines
    • Aniline dyes (particularly benzidine and β-naphthylamine) (choice C)
    • Auramines, phenacetin, and cyclophosphamide
  • Cigarette smoke (choice A)
  • Long term urinary infection (choice B)
  • Schistosoma haematobium is pathogenetically (Related to both urothelial and squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder.)
  • Treated with radiation therapy for prostatic carcinoma

choices.text: Jigsaw pattern composed of cords and nests of urothelial cells invaginating into the lamina propria

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a feature of inverted papilloma?
questions.solution:
INVERTED UROTHELIAL PAPILLOMA

  • It is more commonly seen elderly males
  • Location: Trigone, bladder neck, or prostatic urethra
  • Presents with hematuria and/or obstruction.
  • Cystoscopy: Polypoid and usually pedunculated lesion of smooth contours. (Choice D)
  • Microscopically:
    • The invagination of the epithelium(choics A) with or without cellular atypia (choice C)
    • epithelium may show a foamy or vacuolated cytoplasm.
    • Papillae are absent or present only very focally, (choice B)
    • trabecular arrangement, with peripheral palisading of the tumor cells and central cellular spindling

questions.text: What % chances are there of untreated flat urothelial carcinoma to pregress to invasive urothelial carcinoma?
questions.solution:
CIS (or flat urothelial carcinoma)

  • The presence of cytologically malignant cells within a flat urothelium.
  • CIS (carcinoma in situ) may range from full-thickness cytologic atypia to scattered malignant cells in an otherwise normal urothelium (pagetoid spread).
  • A common feature shared with highgrade papillary urothelial carcinoma is a lack of cohesiveness, which leads to shedding of malignant cells into the urine. When shedding is extensive, only a few CIS cells may be left clinging to a largely denuded basement membrane.
  • Cystoscopy - CIS usually appears as an area of mucosal reddening, granularity, or thickening without an evident intraluminal mass.
  • It is commonly multifocal and may involve most of the bladder surface and extend into the ureters and urethra.
  • If untreated, 50% to 75% of CIS progresses to invasive cancer. (Choice C)
